Introducing Building Equality for another Takeover Thursday! üéâIn honour of LGBTQ+ History Month, we are sharing our platform with networks to share their stories on how they support and provide resource to the community within the built environment. Building Equality is an alliance of construction consultants, engineers, developers, contractors, and institutions who are passionate about working together and harnessing our collective power to drive LGBTQ+ inclusion in the construction, engineering and built environment industry. They have a variety of resources on their website which are free and accessible to everyone, see below some of the posters available from the website.There is much to be done in building a diverse, inclusive and welcoming environment across the industry, and to achieve this, we need to work together to harness our collective power to drive LGBTQ+ inclusion! Check out Building Equality‚Äôs webinars, toolbox talk kits, posters and other resources here: http://ow.ly/pXah50N0iPl#LGBTQHistoryMonth #Inclusive #BuiltEnvironment #Construction #SocialTakeover

tl;dr: help Out in Tech double its reach and impact in 2022 by donating today!We started as a handful of queer New Yorkers, eager to connect with our peers. Since 2013, Out in Tech has grown exponentially. We are now a global community of 40,000 individuals in 16 chapters around the world.We've connected hundreds of our members to new job opportunities, graduated 500+ young people from our mentorship program, built websites for nearly 200 organizations operating in countries where it's illegal to be gay, and created safe virtual and IRL spaces for QTBIPOC and/or trans* individuals in tech.That said, many of our members still face discrimination within their workspace, and little progress has been made on representation of queer people at senior-level roles in the tech industry.Our sights are set on doubling our impact next year to ensure that Out in Tech can offer meaningful career support to queer and trans* people all over the world. We're raising 100k this October to make this dream a reality, and we're currently at 25% of our goal. Support from my network has always meant the world to me. Side by side, I know these wild paths we're traveling will become more productive, more enjoyable, and more diverse. Thank you for making it possible!

We at Security & Safety Things believe diversity makes us stronger. This is why, even though the COVID-19 pandemic limited the ways we could show our pride, we celebrated Cristopher Street Day in a colorful and safe way at our office in Munich. We consider #openness and #inclusivity as a part of our core values. Let‚Äôs stand together and continue to strive for #tolerance and #equalrights for all.Lukas Liese Christin Riederer Nikhilesh Vaishya Zhu Yang Magdalena Hutter Cec√≠lia L. And read until the end!!5 ùóøùó≤ùóÆùòÄùóºùóªùòÄ ùòÑùóµùòÜ ùòÜùóºùòÇ ùòÄùóµùóºùòÇùóπùó± ùó∞ùóµùóÆùóªùó¥ùó≤ ùòÜùóºùòÇùóø ùó∑ùóºùóØ ùó≥ùóøùó≤ùóæùòÇùó≤ùóªùòÅùóπùòÜ‚Äú1. ùóïùóøùóºùóÆùó±ùó≤ùóª ùó¨ùóºùòÇùóø ùó¶ùó∏ùó∂ùóπùóπ ùó¶ùó≤ùòÅ:As a result of changing jobs regularly, you can gain new skills, gain new experience, and become a more well-rounded professional.2. ùó°ùó≤ùó¥ùóºùòÅùó∂ùóÆùòÅùó∂ùóªùó¥ ùó¢ùóΩùóΩùóºùóøùòÅùòÇùóªùó∂ùòÅùòÜ:Negotiating your salary or other compensation can be easier if you frequently change jobs and companies. You will have a better chance of understanding the market value of your skills when you take on new roles.3. ùóòùòÖùóΩùóºùòÄùòÇùóøùó≤ ùòÅùóº ùóªùó≤ùòÑ ùó∂ùóªùó±ùòÇùòÄùòÅùóøùó∂ùó≤ùòÄ ùóÆùóªùó± ùóøùóºùóπùó≤ùòÄ:If you change jobs every few years, you can explore different industries and roles that may be more suitable for you. A job change can help you gain insight into new roles, acquire new skills and certifications, and enhance your resume.4. ùóúùó∫ùóΩùóøùóºùòÉùó≤ùó± ùóπùóºùóªùó¥-ùòÅùó≤ùóøùó∫ ùó∑ùóºùóØ ùòÄùóÆùòÅùó∂ùòÄùó≥ùóÆùó∞ùòÅùó∂ùóºùóª:By changing roles, you‚Äôll have the ability to continually challenge yourself, continue to make an impact, and have better long-term job satisfaction.5. ùóòùòÖùóΩùóÆùóªùó± ùó¨ùóºùòÇùóø ùó°ùó≤ùòÅùòÑùóºùóøùó∏:Every job is a chance to expand your network ‚Äì with potential mentors, collaborators, and employers. Having that wide reach can be incredibly useful on the job market, potentially giving you an advantage over other jobseekers.Changing jobs frequently can be scary, but if you can manage it strategically, you‚Äôll stay up to date, gain new skills and build a wide network that can open many more doors and opportunities for your future.‚ÄùCredits Adnan Manna for that article aboveBut wait!!!What do you think? Is this correct? Or very wrong?What did you do? Did you change jobs frequently (let‚Äôs say every 3-5 years) or stayed long at one job/company. I received a message from a lady who retired from working for "a very mean tyrant boss." These were her words in quotations. She realizes now, that the stress, anxiety, and yelling that she endured was not worth 21 years of her life. She mentioned that his reason for running his business was always that he always did things this way since the 1980s. She wishes she was brave enough to seek better for herself.This made me think:‚ñ™Ô∏èA salary does not guarantee you peace of mind. Change can be good.The most dangerous phrase is: ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve always  done it this way.‚Äù‚ñ™Ô∏èFinding ways to improve can help you avoid regrets later.‚ñ™Ô∏èYour happiness and peace are priceless. My Russian speaking friends keep getting discriminated due to the language they speak. To all of my friends globally, please remember few things:1. Russian speaking does not equal Russian. There were 15 countries in the USSR. All of those countries still have Russian speaking minorities. It doesn't mean they are Russian or identify themselves as Russian. Just like Irish does not equal English or Spanish does not equal Mexican.2. Russian does not equal aggressor. None of the Russians support the war. Some just don't understand what is happening due to the limited information that they are getting. There is no free media left in Russia.3. Ukrainians also speak Russian, some just Russian. Next time you tell a Russian speaker you wont serve them, think about which side you're taking. The person approaching you might have a relative sitting in the bomb shelter right now. 4. Russian name also does not equal Russian. My name is Russian. I was born in Latvia, my parents were born is Latvia. I have Latvian, Ukrainian, Polish, Turkish, Romanian and probably many more ethnicities in me. I grew up in Ireland. My Russian surname was inherited from my great grandfather who was a pacifist, he went through the war and wouldn't ever stand by what's happening right now. Many Ukrainians have Russian surnames too. 5. The anger you're translating on to innocent people is not going to solve the problem, it's going to create more problems and hatred. There are many ways to help, but hating on others is definitely not one of the ways.#StandWithUkraine üá∫üá¶
